post_text: The Martin County School District proudly joins our nation in honoring the heroic first responders in NYC and the Pentagon, and the common citizens of our country who were called into action to bring goodness out of evil on September 11, 2001. post_text: So proud of our standout National Merit Scholarship semifinalists from South Fork High School! #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š
shared_text:
South Fork High School
September 9 at 6:22 PM Â·

South Forkâ€™s National Merit Semifinalists: Three South Fork High School seniors have been named Semifinalists in the 2021 National Merit Scholarship Program. The National Merit Scholarship Program is a renowned academic competition for recognition and scholarships that began in 1955.

This yearâ€™s competition began in October 2019 when more than 1.5 million juniors in approximately 21,000 high schools took the PSAT/NMSQT, which served as an initial screen of program entrants. The highest-scoring participants in each state, representing less than one percent of our nationâ€™s high school seniors, were named Semifinalists on a state-representational basis. Finalists will be announced in the spring of 2021.

Congratulations to the following National Merit Scholarship Semifinalists from the Martin County School District:

South Fork High School

Stephen R. Patten
Samuel G. Reeder
Austin Leo Thomas

ğŸSCHOOL BOARD SET TO INTERVIEW FINALISTS FOR APPOINTED SUPERINTENDENCYğŸ

During its Special meeting held September 2, 2020, the Martin County School Board selected candidates from its list of semifinalists to move forward in the hiring process for the appointed superintendency. The finalists will be interviewed collectively and individually by Board Members on September 16 and 17, 2020. Each candidate will also participate in a Q&A session, answering questions submitted by members of the community.

The four finalists are:

ğŸDr. John D. Millay, recently retired Superintendent - Meade County School District (Kentucky)

ğŸDr. Lori M. Romano, current Director of Career, Technical and Adult Education Programs - Pasco County School District

ğŸDr. Peter B. Licata, current Regional Superintendent - Palm Beach County School District

ğŸDr. Michael J. Dunsmore, former Superintendent - Wayne County Public Schools (North Carolina)

*Candidate Thomas Phelps has withdrawn his name from consideration effective September 10, 2020.

Please click the link below to learn more. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

MARTINSCHOOLS.ORG

The role of each committee is to ensure that the District is spending funds generated by the millage and sales tax increases as specified in each voter-approved referendum.

Spread the word! The District will launch a remote learning opportunity - VPK Flex - for students enrolled in Voluntary Prekindergarten programs on September 1, 2020.

All remote VPK students will be assigned to a teaching team physically based at Bessey Creek Elementary School where content and materials will be prepared each week.

A complete MCSD enrollment packet and signed State of Florida VPK Certificate is required for registration. Please contact Patricia Little at 219-1893, x 44100 or email littlep@martinschools.org to enroll. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

ğŸ½ REMOTE LEARNING MEALSğŸ½

School meals are available to all students enrolled in District-operated schools (free, reduced and paid meal status) as part of the National School Lunch Program.

Food and Nutrition Services has developed an order sheet that parents/guardians of students enrolled in remote learning will submit weekly.

Families will pick up a week's worth of meals at one of three locations: The School of Science, Math & Technology, JD Parker Parent Page, Port Salerno Elementary School or Warfield Elementary School. Meal distribution will take place from 3 -4 p.m. on Tuesdays.

Please click the link below to learn more. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

post_text:
ğŸ¶HANDS ON LESSONS LEARNED IN REMOTE SETTINGğŸ¶

Whether in the classroom or via livestream, MCSD teachers make lessons come alive for students!

During one of her remote learning livestreams on Tuesday, August 18, South Fork High School Veterinary Assisting teacher Stacy Reddish found herself presenting the lesson of a lifetime.

A student joined the Zoom and began asking questions about her dog who was in labor. The student was able to show her classmates the delivery of 10 puppies, one of whom was in distress. Ms. Reddish instructed the student on how to tie off the umbilical cord and remove the mucus plugs. The student was able to save the puppy, but the mom was exhausted. Ms. Reddish directed the student to gather the pups in a laundry basket with warm towels and take the mom to the vet. All puppies and mom are doing very well today! #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

Students may transition to remote learning if necessary - please contact your child's school if you have any questions about beginning the remote learning process.

Please click the link below to review our daily symptom screening tool for students.

We appreciate your support as we work collaboratively to protect the health and safety of our students and staff. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

MCSO SEARCHING FOR 9-YEAR OLD CITRUS GROVE ELEMENTARY SCHOOL STUDENT WHO DID NOT RETURN HOME FROM SCHOOL

Multiple sheriffâ€™s units, including aviation, SRO deputies, detectives, and road patrol deputies are searching for a 9-year old Citrus Grove Elementary School student who did not return home from school today. The mother of 9-year old Shirley Pluta says the child did not get off of the school bus in the community of Cobblestone/Stuart West in Palm City. Units are searching the area of the school and the community where the child lives.

Shirley was last seen wearing a pink sweater, pink pants and black shoes. If you have any information about Shirley Pluta, please call 911.

post_text:
ğŸEDUCATING ALL STUDENTS FOR SUCCESSğŸ

TCPalm - Students across the Martin County School District have returned to campus for the first time since March, when schools first closed because of the Coronavirus pandemic. It was a first day of school unlike anything anyone had ever seen before, said Superintendent Laurie J. Gaylord.

The first day went well despite challenges she said, thanking staff for working hard to prepare schools and classrooms for social distancing and education in the midst of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Masks were a non-issue among students and teachers on the first day. All but two students at the seven sites Mrs. Gaylord visited on Tuesday reported to school with a mask. Extra masks are always available for students who forget theirs, she shared.

"I kind of like (the mask)," said Stuart Middle School student Sam McCullough. The 13-year-old said he was glad to be back in school.

"It's better with the teacher in front of you," he said. "She can repeat (instructions) multiple times." #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š
shared_text:
TCPALM.COM
Today is the day: Martin County students return to schools for the first time since March

post_text:
ğŸYOU'VE ASKED, WE'VE ANSWEREDğŸ

Q: If I elect to have my child participate in the traditional, in-person school option, will they be able to ride the bus to and from school?

A: Yes. Students who are eligible for school bus transportation as defined in School Board Policy 8600 will continue to be eligible to ride the bus. To be eligible for transportation, students must live more than two (2) miles from their home-zoned school OR be eligible for transportation due to a documented hazardous walking condition (as defined in Chapter 1006.23, Florida Statutes). On February 18, 2020, the Martin County School Board voted to eliminate the seats available and grandfathering programs that previously allowed students who lived less than two (2) miles from their home-zoned school to be eligible for transportation.

ğŸšPlease click the link below to view bus routes for the 20-21 school year. ğŸš

#ALLMartinğŸ‘Š

ğŸYOU'VE ASKED, WE'VE ANSWEREDğŸ

Q: Will students, staff and visitors be required to wear masks? If so, will they wear them at all times?

A: Students will be required to wear masks on school buses and on campuses when it is not possible to keep the recommended 6 feet of social distance from others (changing classes, arriving/departing campus, in the hallways, and in classrooms where 6 feet of space is not available between students).

Social distancing cannot be guaranteed and is dependent on the number of students and staff in any location at a given time.

All designs and wording present on masks must adhere to the dress code regulations found in the Districtâ€™s Code of Student Conduct. Staff and visitors will be required to wear masks when social distancing is not practical or possible.

Please click the photo to learn how you can help your child become more comfortable with wearing his/her mask. #ALLMartinğŸ‘Š

Q: How will the District enforce the rule that students must wear masks when social distancing is not possible? I do not want my child exposed to illness because another student(s) refuse(s) to follow the rules.

A: District staff hold the responsibility of ensuring students are wearing their masks at all appropriate times as previously outlined or specifically noted otherwise. Students will be reminded that masks are required while in school and continued refusal to comply with this requirement could result in disciplinary action as outlined below.

To view answers to additional frequently asked questions, please visit martinschools.org/reopening. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

Q: If my child participates in traditional (in-person) school, what will social distancing look like? Will desks be placed 6 feet apart?

A: Social distancing will be a primary objective and desks will be spaced 6 feet apart to the greatest extent possible based on class size and space. Social distancing cannot be guaranteed and is dependent on the number of students and staff present in any location at a given time. Masks are required to be worn when social distancing is not possible.

Please click the link below to view additional answers to frequently asked questions. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

post_text:
ğŸYOU'VE ASKED, WE'VE ANSWEREDğŸ

Q: Whatâ€™s the difference between quarantine and isolation? How do I know if I need to do one or the other?

A: Quarantine keeps someone who might have been exposed to the virus away from others. â€œQuarantine is for contacts.â€

Isolation separates people who are infected with COVID-19 away from people who are not infected. â€œIsolation is for those who are infected/ill.â€

Quarantine protocol: Anyone who has been in close contact (within 6 feet for longer than 15 minutes) with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 - whether one or both parties were wearing a mask or not - must quarantine themselves.

Isolation protocol: Anyone who has tested positive for COVID-19, anyone who has symptoms of COVID-19 and is able to recover at home, or anyone who has no symptoms (asymptomatic) but has tested positive for COVID-19- must isolate themselves.

View additional answers to frequently asked questions at martinschools.org/reopening. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

post_text:
ğŸšŒTRANSPORTATION INFOğŸšŒ

Students who are eligible for transportation as defined in School Board Policy 8600 will continue to be eligible for this service in the 2020-2021 school year.

To be eligible for transportation, students must live more than two (2) miles from their home-zoned school OR be eligible for transportation due to a documented hazardous walking condition (as defined in Chapter 1006.23, Florida Statutes).

On February 18, 2020, the Martin County School Board voted to eliminate the seats available and grandfathering programs that previously allowed students who lived less than two (2) miles from their home-zoned school to be eligible for transportation. More information on this decision is available here: http://go.boarddocs.com/fl/martin/Board.nsf/goto?open&id=9ZYL9Z5032D2.

Bus routes for the 20-21 school year are available below. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

post_text:
ğŸ˜· #MaskUpMCSDğŸ˜·

Masks are required to be worn by students, staff and visitors any time it is not possible to keep the recommended 6 feet of social distance from others on school district property. Social distancing cannot be guaranteed and is dependent on the number of students and staff present in any location at a given time.

All designs and wording present on masks must adhere to the dress code regulations found in the Districtâ€™s Code of Student Conduct. Students and staff will be provided with instructions on when and how to properly wear, remove and store masks.

Residents can pick up reusable, cloth masks at one of the six Martin County Library System branches during normal operating hours, while supplies last. Distribution is limited to 2 masks per person and no more than 8 masks per household.

Visit martinschools.org/reopening to learn more about health/safety protocols and review answers to frequently asked questions. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

post_text:
ğŸYOU'VE ASKED, WE'VE ANSWEREDğŸ

Q: Whatâ€™s the difference between quarantine and isolation? How do I know if I need to do one or the other?

A: Quarantine keeps someone who might have been exposed to the virus away from others. â€œQuarantine is for contacts.â€

Isolation separates people who are infected with COVID-19 away from people who are not infected. â€œIsolation is for those who are infected/ill.â€

Quarantine protocol: Anyone who has been in close contact (within 6 feet for longer than 15 minutes) with someone who has tested positive for COVID-19 - whether one or both parties were wearing a mask or not - must quarantine themselves.

Isolation protocol: Anyone who has tested positive for COVID-19, anyone who has symptoms of COVID-19 and is able to recover at home, or anyone who has no symptoms (asymptomatic) but has tested positive for COVID-19- must isolate themselves.

View additional answers to frequently asked questions at martinschools.org/reopening. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

Q: If I don't currently have a laptop or Chromebook for my child(ren), can I obtain one from the District? Will the District support my child's device if we choose to use one from home?

A: Yes. The District continues to support distance learning by distributing devices to students that do not have a previously issued District device to use outside the classroom.

These devices will be distributed to K-8 students from Aug 5- Aug 7 at their enrolled school site for the 2020-2021 school year. High school students will continue to use their District-issued Laptops for Learning (L4L) devices.

A device will be available for ALL enrolled students in the household.

We encourage students to obtain a District-issued device during the deployment from Aug 5 - Aug 7. Students may use personal devices, but District staff will not provide tech support (hardware and software) for personal devices.

Q: If I choose the traditional option, what will happen if my child's school or all schools close again like they did last school year?

A:If schools are ordered to be closed by the Governor or the local health department, schools will begin remote learning for everyone as per the District's Back to School Decision Tree. A structured schedule for instruction and teaching will be made available at that time. Student expectations for attendance and learning will be made clear. Ongoing training for teachers will continue throughout the fall to support engaging online instruction.

post_text:
ğŸYOU'VE ASKED, WE'VE ANSWEREDğŸ

Q: If I elect to have my child participate in the traditional, in-person school option, will they be able to ride the bus to and from school?

A: Yes. Students who are eligible for school bus transportation as defined in School Board Policy 8600 will continue to be eligible to ride the bus. To be eligible for transportation, students must live more than two (2) miles from their home-zoned school OR be eligible for transportation due to a documented hazardous walking condition (as defined in Chapter 1006.23, Florida Statutes). On February 18, 2020, the Martin County School Board voted to eliminate the seats available and grandfathering programs that previously allowed students who lived less than two (2) miles from their home-zoned school to be eligible for transportation. More information on this decision is available here: http://go.boarddocs.com/fl/martin/Board.nsf/goto?open&id=9ZYL9Z5032D2.

#ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

ğŸ SUPERINTENDENT SEARCH ğŸ

TCPalm - Forty-five candidates met Wednesday's application deadline to be considered by the School Board in its search for the next leader of the Martin County School District.

This is the first time the School Board will appoint its superintendent. Voters agreed to give that responsibility to the Board in November 2018.

The top candidate will succeed Laurie J. Gaylord, whose second term as the elected superintendent will expire in November. Superintendent Gaylord announced in May she would retire at that time and would not apply for the appointed superintendency.

Please click the link below to learn more about the applicants and search process. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

Q: Will a student be permitted to take some courses in person at the school building and their remaining classes at home?

A: This concept is being investigated for feasibility. If a student is enrolled in a course first period that he/she would like to take in-person, the travel time to go home after first period would not allow him/her to participate in second period remotely. Once student commitments have been made, staff will investigate this possibility for potential changes to make part-time remote learning and part-time in-person learning possible. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

Q: If I choose the remote learning option, will my middle or high school student be able to participate in programs or academies such as International Baccalaureate, Cambridge AICE, Advanced Placement, Career & Technical Education (CTE) courses or AVID?

A: The remote learning option will allow students to livestream directly into their teachersâ€™ classrooms at school. While many aspects of lessons will translate seamlessly into the remote learning format, some courses include hands-on lessons and experiences that will not be available in the remote learning environment.

*Note: In-person attendance may be required in specialty programs when work-based learning and/or Industry Certification requires the demonstration of technical skills attainment. Please contact your child's site instructor with questions.

Q: What is the protocol for school closure in the event a school receives notice that a student or staff member has tested positive for COVID-19? Will the District notify parents?

A: If a student or staff member tests positive for COVID-19, the District will work closely with DOH Martin to provide contact tracing to ensure that anyone who came in close contact with the Case+ person will be notified by DOH Martin to determine exposure, quarantine measures and testing, if necessary.

Decisions about the closure of schools will be made in partnership with local and state health officials.

Have additional questions? Please visit https://www.martinschools.org/Page/9551.

post_text:
ğŸYOU'VE ASKED, WE'VE ANSWEREDğŸ

Q: Will the remote learning option be identical to the distance learning we experienced during the final months of last school year?

A: The remote learning option for the 2020-2021 school year is not the same as the distance learning families participated in last school year.

In order to maintain instructional continuity, students participating in the remote learning option will receive direct instruction from their classroom teacher(s) through the livestreaming of each class.

Students who choose this option will maintain their enrollment status at their assigned school and follow their assigned course schedule. Attendance will be taken each period. Students/teachers will follow the same curriculum sequence as their peers in school and can easily transition to in-person attendance in school when they are ready. Services including mental health, counseling, and interventions will be made available. Parents should provide adult supervision and support for young children.
#ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

Q: If my child participates in traditional, in-person school, what will social distancing look like? Will desks be placed 6 feet apart? Will students have to wear masks in their classrooms if their desks are placed 6 feet apart?

A: Social distancing will be a primary objective and desks will be spaced 6 feet apart to the greatest extent possible based on class size and space. Social distancing cannot be guaranteed and is dependent on the numbers of students and staff in any location at a given time. Students will be required to wear masks when it is not possible to maintain the recommended 6 feet of social distance from others.

Q: Will students, staff and visitors be required to wear masks? If so, will they wear them at all times?

A: At this time, students will be required to wear masks on school buses and on campuses when it is not possible to keep the recommended 6 feet of social distance from others (changing classes, arriving/departing campus, in the hallways, and in classrooms where 6 feet of space is not available between students).

Social distancing cannot be guaranteed and is dependent on the number of students and staff in any location at a given time. All designs and wording present on masks must adhere to the dress code regulations found in the Districtâ€™s Code of Student Conduct.

Staff and visitors will be required to wear masks when social distancing is not practical or possible. Students and staff will be provided with instructions on when and how to properly wear masks, remove masks, and store masks.

ğŸPARENT COMMITMENT FORMğŸ

To streamline the choice process for next school year , parents/guardians who would like to enroll their children in Option 1: Traditional (In School) Learning will NOT need to take any action.

Parents/guardians who would prefer to have their child(ren) participate in Option 2: Remote Learning MUST complete a commitment form to enroll their child(ren) in this option. Form responses will be accepted until 11:59 p.m. on Sunday, July 19. The form is available in English and Spanish - please click the link below for access.

Any parent/guardian needing assistance or more information about school reopening may contact their child's school directly or email MCSDReopening@martinschools.org. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

MARTINSCHOOLS.ORG
School Reopening / Parent Commitment Form

post_text:
ğŸYOU'VE ASKED, WE'VE ANSWEREDğŸ

Q: Why would the District choose to fully reopen schools when COVID-19 cases are rising in our community and state?

A: The decision to reopen schools at this time is in direct response to the Florida Department of Educationâ€™s Emergency Order 2020-EO-06, which was issued and signed by Education Commissioner Corcoran on July 6, 2020.

Within the Emergency Order, Commissioner Corcoran outlines that brick and mortar schools will need to reopen at least five days a week for all students beginning in August or risk the loss of funding. All school districts in Florida are required to submit their reopening plans to the DOE by July 31, 2020. We are working with our community partners to mitigate risk and protect the health and safety of staff and students. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

post_text:
ğŸ’µOUR DOLLARS, OUR DISTRICTğŸ’µ

In November 2018, Martin County voters generously approved a half-cent sales tax increase to provide funding for a variety of critical capital projects in the Martin County School District. Stay tuned here on Facebook as we show you exactly how your dollars are being used to repair, renovate and upgrade our schools and facilities!

Jensen Beach Elementary School will be completely replaced using funds generated by the half-cent sales tax increase. The School Board approved the Construction Management at Risk Services (CMR) pre-construction contract on June 16.

Learn more about current, ongoing and future projects: https://tinyurl.com/MCSDOurDollarsOurDistrict.
#ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

post_text:
âš–ï¸ CONSTITUTIONAL COMPETITION âš–ï¸

Social distancing didn't stop students from Jensen Beach High School, Martin County High School and South Fork High School from participating in the final round of the fifth annual Constitutional Academic Competition this morning!

This annual competition allows YMCA of The Treasure Coast Youth in Government (YIG) students to research a designated constitutional issue and present their arguments in a debate-style format before a sitting judge. In addition to gaining valuable research and debate experience, students compete for scholarship funds as part of the process. Students were asked to research and debate the relevancy of the Electoral College before Judge Alan O. Forst of the Fourth District Court of Appeal today.

Thank you to the Center for Constitutional Values and Judge Forst for providing our students with this valuable learning experience.

Click the link below to learn more and view this year's winners! #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

post_text:
With discussions of race at the forefront of local and national debate, individuals, local governments and national brands have been forced to reckon with the role they play in responding to calls for equity.

School districts are no different.

"When I look at our world and what our role is, I do believe education is key," Superintendent Laurie J. Gaylord told the Martin County School Board Tuesday. "What we teach our children matters, what we model for our children matters and we do need to talk to our children about racism."

TCPalm has made this story available to subscribers only. Please click the link below to read more. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

ğŸKINDERGARTEN REGISTRATIONğŸ

The Martin County School District will begin virtual kindergarten registration for the 2020-2021 school year on Monday, June 1, 2020. Parents of children who will turn five on or before September 1, 2020, are encouraged to participate in the virtual registration process.

To participate in kindergarten registration, parents/guardians must:

ğŸComplete all enrollment forms

ğŸProvide a copy of their child's birth certificate

ğŸProvide immunization records and proof of a current physical examination

ğŸProvide two proofs of residency (current utility bill with address, current year property tax bill, deed of home, lease agreement, mortgage, copy of auto insurance policy, home purchase contract, declaration of domicile, Florida driver's license, or Florida identification card).

Please click the link below to access the interactive enrollment forms. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

post_text:
ğŸBEGINNING THE NEXT CHAPTER IN THE AGE OF COVID-19 ğŸ

Cindi Bocken teaches second grade at Warfield Elementary School in Village of Indiantown, FL Government. After 33 years of teaching, she decided in December that she would retire. She never imagined ending her career through a computer screen.

"This was a gift. Teaching was a gift to me, and it's real hard to walk away from your gift," said Bocken. "I know I've touched my kids' lives, and I've hugged them before and I'm gonna have to accept that's enough for now and maybe in the future, I'll be able to see them again." #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š
shared_text:
WPTV.COM
Teacher weighs in on retiring during COVID-19 pandemic

post_text:
ğŸ“#MCSDSeniorStoriesğŸ“

Please join us in congratulating Martin County High School senior Megan Krevitz!

"Megan started high school participating in the Culinary Academy and OPUS Choir, which she loved," proud mom Tammi Krevitz shares. "She's also participated in the Martin County 4-H program for the past 7 years, showing various animals. Megan's pretty easy going (even after getting up well before school to drive 20 miles round trip to check on her fair project for 5 mths), with an infectious laugh and sense of humor her family loves. She's known for years she wants to be in culinary, preferably baking. She'll be pursuing a degree in Culinary Management at IRSC - Indian River State College, and one day would love to open her own bakery! We are so proud - and are especially thankful for Mr. Whittle, Mr. Thomas and Ms Valmyr, for being such great role models and teachers - you guys are awesome, and your dedication makes a big difference in these kids' lives!"

To share an #MCSDSeniorStoryğŸ“ about yourself or a loved one, please visit tinyurl.com/MCSDSeniorStories. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

Please join us in congratulating Martin County High School senior Hannah Jones!

"I am a Band student turned Bio-Med major who is going to Keiser University," Hannah shares. "I love science and music has always been a part of my life. Shout out to my favorite teachers through the past four years - Ms. Valmyr, Coach Williams, Ms. Croy, Mr. Fread, Ms. Fitzpatrick, Mr. Patrick (who is no longer at MCHS), Ms. Carbone, Mr. Biancone and Ms. Gundrania were some of the greats! I am so happy to have been part of County for the 4 years I was there. All of the bittersweet memories will be forever kept."

ğŸ“#MCSDSeniorStoriesğŸ“

Please join us in congratulating Martin County High School senior Denny Sica!

"I've enjoyed going to Martin County and making friends along the way," Denny shares. "It's been wonderful and also a lot of fun when participating in activities. I have learned a lot at school and enjoyed learning with my teachers - they've helped me so much and for this, I have made it where I am now. I thank them for everything they have done to help me finish school. I thank Ms. Aronoff for helping me graduate this year, and for always telling me I can do it and not give up. She has always been there for me through this journey. It wasn't easy, but here I am. Also, thank you to all of my other teachers for helping me."

To share an #MCSDSeniorStoryğŸ“ about yourself or a loved one, please visit tinyurl.com/MCSDSeniorStories. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

ğŸ“#MCSDSeniorStoriesğŸ“

Please join us in congratulating Jensen Beach High School senior Stephanie Weil!

"Stephanie is graduating from JBHS and will be pursuing a degree in elementary education at the University of South Florida," proud mom Elisa Weil shares. "She plans to obtain a master's degree in special education - she has always loved working with kids, from being a homework helper at Jensen Beach Elementary School to volunteering her time working with preschoolers at the Gertrude Walden Center. She has also volunteered with the Special Olympics Florida - Martin County and spent a year taking an executive internship working with special needs classmates. She has such a big heart and her future students will be lucky to have her!"

To share an #MCSDSeniorStoryğŸ“ about yourself or a loved one, please visit tinyurl.com/MCSDSeniorStories. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

ğŸ’¡ğŸ“SHINING THE SPOTLIGHT ON OUR SENIORSğŸ’¡ğŸ“

The Martin County School District will celebrate the graduating #Classof2020 with additional community-wide ceremonies of lights this week!

At 8:20 p.m. (20:20 military time) May 20-22, District-operated high schools will recognize this year's senior class with spotlight shows that will be displayed across the night sky from each campus. The light shows will coincide with the original graduation ceremony dates for each school - May 20 for Martin County High School, May 21 for Jensen Beach High School and May 22 for South Fork High School. Graduation ceremonies have been rescheduled for late July and will be held in accordance with all public health guidelines that are in place at that time.

Don't forget to show YOUR support for Martin County seniors by turning on your exterior/porch lights at 8:20 and viewing the spotlight shows each evening! #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š
shared_text:
MARTINSCHOOLS.ORG
Shining the Spotlight on the Class of 2020

ğŸ“#MCSDSeniorStories ğŸ“

Please join us in congratulating South Fork High School senior Kaylee Carroll!

"This is my senior Kaylee Carroll, who will be a proud graduate of South Fork High School," mom Tammy Carroll shares. "Kaylee has been in Choir since elementary school. She also was in Drama for a couple of years and was a part of the Junior International Thespian Society. Kaylee was a part of three school plays in middle school and also while in middle school she had three poems published in a book. Kaylee would like to be a singer/songwriter. She loves to play Call of Duty and other games with her family. She loves to bake and sing on karaoke apps and sometimes at weddings. Kaylee's faith is also extremely important to her."

To share an #MCSDSeniorStoryğŸ“ about yourself or a loved one, please visit tinyurl.com/MCSDSeniorStories. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

ğŸ“#MCSDSeniorStories ğŸ“

Please join us in congratulating Martin County High School senior David Tyler Jackson!

"David, who goes by Tyler, has shown such strength and perseverance these last four years of high school," proud mother Amy Jackson shares. "We are so proud of him! He marched in the marching band all four years and tried out culinary class, but has fallen in love with drafting. He is so creative and full of life! He loves to snowboard, ice skate and play video games, but his favorite hobby of all is paintball! Tyler will move on next year to be an owl at Florida Atlantic University. He plans to pursue a career in architecture. Shout out to all of Martin County faculty and staff for helping to guide our students to be their very best!

To share an #MCSDSeniorStoryğŸ“ about yourself or a loved one, please visit tinyurl.com/MCSDSeniorStories. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

post_text:
ğŸ“#MCSDSeniorStoriesğŸ“

Please join us in congratulating Jensen Beach High School senior Kelly Groth!

"Kelly has been a member of the JBHS Falcon Band and Color Guard for four years," proud mother Kay Groth shares. "She has played trombone for JB Squared (Jazz band) and the JBHS Symphonic Band all four years. During the marching season, Kelly does Color Guard. Color Guard has become her passion. She was captain of the guard for the past two years and also performed during the winter guard season all four years. Last summer, she toured the country with The Academy Drum and Bugle Corps. She traveled over 11,000 miles on a bus competing with 150 other corps members doing various Drum Corps International (DCI) events. Kelly plans to attend Georgia Tech in the fall and major in Industrial Design."

To share an #MCSDSeniorStoryğŸ“ about yourself or a loved one, please visit tinyurl.com/MCSDSeniorStories. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

post_text:
ğŸ“#MCSDSeniorStoriesğŸ“

Please join us in congratulating South Fork High School senior Gabriella Montoya!

"My favorite memories about high school are getting ready for the Martin Bowl (biggest football game of the year) or playing in volleyball games and looking up at the crowd knowing all those people were here for us," Gabriella shares. "I also enjoyed walking the halls - making people laugh and smile - and knowing that these are my last moments of being a child and soon I will be an adult. After high school I plan on going to IRSC - Indian River State College and getting my ASN/BSN or going for EMT schooling and then to the Air Force to pursue my dream of being a flight medic! I want to say thank you to all of my teachers for helping me through the rough times and making me laugh and smile in my worst moods. I'll miss all of you!"

To share an #MCSDSeniorStoryğŸ“ about yourself or a loved one, please visit tinyurl.com/MCSDSeniorStories. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

It has never been easier to show your support for our graduating seniors, Martin County!

Please follow these simple steps to update your Facebook profile picture with our MCSD #Classof2020 frame:

1) Navigate to your personal page in the Facebook app
2) Click the ğŸ“¸ icon on your profile picture
3) Click "Add Frame"
4) Search for "MCSDGrad2020"

You may also click the following link to access the frame from your desktop computer or web browser: tinyurl.com/MCSDFrame.

Don't forget to share this information with your family and friends! #ALLINMartin

1) Navigate to your personal page in the Facebook app
2) Click the ğŸ“¸ icon on your profile picture
3) Click "Add Frame"
4) Search for "MCSDGrad2020"

You may also click the following link to access the frame from your desktop computer or web browser: tinyurl.com/MCSDFrame.

Don't forget to share this information with your family and friends! #ALLINMartin

ğŸ“#MCSDSeniorStoriesğŸ“

Please join us in congratulating South Fork High School senior David Vargas!

"I introduce you to my senior, David Vargas," proud mom Maribel Vargas shares. "David is a kind, compassionate and responsible young man. During the past few years at South Fork, David has taken Honors classes and has completed some college courses at IRSC - Indian River State College thru the dual enrollment program. He has been a part of the ROTC program over the past four years as well. David enjoys listening to music and spending time with his friends and family. He really enjoys working at the job he has held over the past three years. David will begin his college career at Indian River State College. We are so grateful for the wonderful staff at SFHS for all they do for the students. We are also so very proud of our graduate!"

To share an #MCSDSeniorStoryğŸ“ about yourself or a loved one, please visit tinyurl.com/MCSDSeniorStories. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

Please join us in congratulating Martin County High School senior Tyler Whaley!

"My son Tyler Whaley has come a long way in a short time," mom Kristina Brock shares. "I am so proud of him graduating from Martin County High School. His plans after graduation are to take a gap year and work to save up money before going to IRSC - Indian River State College or possibly to Palm Beach State College. He would like to major in English Literature and later to enter into a teaching program in order to teach English to high school students. He would like to give a shoutout to Mrs. Gardenier for inspiring him to follow a path towards an English degree."

While we never run out of things to celebrate in the Martin County School District, today's announcement from the Florida Department of Education has us literally jumping for joy!

Mrs. Angela "Angie" Gilbride, a hometown Martin County educator and assistant principal of Warfield Elementary School in the Village of Indiantown, FL Government, has been named one of three finalists for Florida's Assistant Principal of the Year Award!

Click the following link to learn more about Mrs. Gilbride and her efforts to ensure all Warfield Elementary students are educated for success: https://tinyurl.com/y9q3ebu3. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

Please join us in congratulating Jensen Beach High School senior Emily Cordero!

"Emily is dual enrolled and is an AP Honor Student," mom Tammy Cordero shares. "She has been a member of the JBHS Falcon Band family for 4 years. Emily is a member of the National Honor Society, Mu Alpha Theta, Robotics Club and Winter Guard. She is a Math nominee for The Palm Beach Post's Pathfinders Scholarship. We feel blessed to have had the support and guidance of Jennifer Ali, who has been instrumental in helping Emily navigate her successful high school career. Emily has been accepted and will be attending Columbia University in the City of New York in the fall."

post_text:
ğŸSCHOOL BOARD TO BEGIN ACCEPTING APPLICATIONS FOR APPOINTED SUPERINTENDENTğŸ

The Martin County School Board will begin accepting applications from candidates interested in becoming the Martin County School District's appointed Superintendent of Schools on Friday, May 15, 2020. Interested candidates and members of the community are invited to review the job description and search brochure on the Superintendent Search website (link below). The Board will continue to promote civic engagement by selecting members of the community who represent a cross-section of Martin County to serve on a Citizens Advisory Committee as part of the search process.

The approved hiring timeline has the appointed Superintendent of Schools being named by September 22, 2020, and beginning their employment with the District on November 17, 2020. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

ğŸ“ GRADUATION CEREMONY DATES ANNOUNCED ğŸ“

In a video message delivered earlier today to members of the #Classof2020, Superintendent Laurie J. Gaylord announced dates for schools' graduation ceremonies that are being planned for late July. District staff will continue to collaborate with public health and safety experts to ensure the ceremonies remain in complete compliance with all CDC guidelines that are in place at that time.

Each school's ceremony will take place on campus at 9 am:

ğŸ“Martin County High School - Wednesday, July 22, 2020
ğŸ“ Jensen Beach High School - Thursday, July 23, 2020
ğŸ“ South Fork High School - Friday, July 24, 2020

Students and their families are encouraged to monitor their Senior Class Google Classrooms for additional updates and information about the ceremonies.

Click below watch Superintendent Gaylord's video message. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

He decided to join the swim team even though he had never competed before, and now plans to join the U.S. Navy with the goal of becoming a SEAL (which has been his dream since he was 4). He'll leave May 26, 2020, to begin his service to our nation. ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

To share a senior story about yourself or a loved one, please visit tinyurl.com/MCSDSeniorStories. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ ENSURING A CORRECT COUNT ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸

Health clinics. Fire departments. Schools. Roads and highways. The U.S. Census helps to shape many different aspects of our community.

Once a decade, Americans come together to participate in the Census, with data generated being used to shape our future. A correct count is critical for all of us in Martin County, as numbers are used to determine federal representation and funding for a variety of programs and initiatives in our community.

The 2020 Census asks a few simple questions about you and everyone who was living with you as of April 1, 2020. Please complete your form online, by phone or by mail. Click the link below begin. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

Moore, Ms. Lavelle and Ms. Allen," her mother shares. "Some of her best school memories are from band trips, puzzling after AP exams in Mr. Pigott's class and reading Oscar Wilde with Ms. Fabrizio. She is really looking forward to starting her next chapter and will be attending Duke University in the fall while pursuing a degree in Psychology. Thanks, JBHS, for getting her ready to SOAR!"

Please join us in congratulating South Fork High School senior Mabel Howe!

"We are so very proud of our daughter," Mabel's mother, Bridget Howe, shares. "She will be graduating with her Certified Vet Assistant certificate. She's been awarded a scholarship from the Martin County Fair and Youth Livestock Show and one from Martin County 4-H. She plans on completing her A.A. at IRSC - Indian River State College, becoming a vet tech and working with small and large animals. She is extremely thankful to Mrs. Reddish for being so supportive and an incredible resource of information in her high school years. She will certainly miss her Veterinary Assisting classes at South Fork and seeing Mrs. Reddish daily."

ğŸ“#MCSDSeniorStoriesğŸ“

Please join us in congratulating Martin County High School senior Sarah Repetti!

"I am very grateful for all of my teachers and staff members at Martin County High all of these years," Sarah shares. â€œI will miss having the opportunity to say goodbye to all of them, but hope to see many of them at the graduation ceremony that is tentatively planned for the end of July! Spending most of my years on the stage, whether dancing, singing or acting, and spending three fantastic years with Mrs. Pastore at MCHS Theater Department, I am thrilled to announce that I have been accepted and also received a scholarship into IRSC - Indian River State College's Performing and Visual Art Department! I get to remain local for a couple more years on the Treasure Coast where I was born and raised! I love you, Mrs. Pastore!!! Thank you for believing in me! Wishing my fellow 2020 Graduates all the best! Thanks for the memories!"

To share an #MCSDSeniorStoryğŸ“ about yourself or a loved one, please visit tinyurl.com/MCSDSeniorStories. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š

When schools were closed because of the novel coronavirus, Jensen Beach High School senior Patrick Eaton decided to step up.

He recently began working at Stuart Rehabilitation and Healthcare, a short- and long-term care facility, as a patient care assistant â€” all while completing his senior-year requirements.

"I do a lot of the same type of things the (certified nursing assistants) do, like bathing patients, feeding them, making their beds and getting them ready for the day," Eaton said.

post_text:
ğŸ‰CELEBRATING OUR TEACHERS AND COMMUNITYğŸ‰

In just 24 hours after the launch of the #ThankATeacherMCSD campaign, more than 200 students, parents and community members have taken the time to write messages of gratitude to their favorite Martin County School District educators.

While our plan was to share these messages during national #ThankATeacher Week (May 4 - 8), we just can't keep these heartwarming messages to ourselves a minute longer!

Today's first message goes out to Ms. Forrester of Stuart Middle School/ Stuart Middle School PTSA from student Ella Hart.

To submit your message of gratitude to one of our #MCSDMagnificent teachers, please click here: tinyurl.com/thankateacherMCSD.

post_text:
ğŸ“ FALCON SENIOR SOARS ğŸ“

Adults aren't the only healthcare workers responding to the call to assist patients during the COVID-19 pandemic.

Patrick Eaton is a senior CNA student enrolled in Jensen Beach High School's Academy of Health Sciences. He recently landed a position as a Patient Care Assistant at the nursing home where he received his clinical training earlier this year.

As COVID-19 began to spread throughout our nation, Patrick didn't back away from his calling. He continues to serve elderly and disabled residents and pursue his passion, undoubtedly making a difference in the lives of many during a very uncertain time.

"[Patrick] should be commended for his dedication to the medical profession and his community," JBHS Health Science instructor Adam Day shared. "His initiative to start working in this extremely challenging field during this incredibly important time makes Patrick my personal hero. He is absolutely SOARING above and beyond." #ALLINMartin ğŸ‘Š

ğŸ¤— SOCIAL EMOTIONAL SUPPORT ğŸ¤—

Parents â€“ your children are home. You may be working from home or still reporting to work. How did we get here? At the very least, itâ€™s safe to say, our lives have changed considerably due to the spread of the Coronavirus (COVID-19).

BASE Education has launched a new program to help educate students and guide them through the current days of uncertainty - the Coronavirus (COVID-19) Course.

Course content includes:

- What is the Coronavirus and how does it affect us?

- How does it spread, and how do we contain it?

- How to stay healthy mentally and physically at home.

- The how and why of maintaining respectful behavior in these uncertain times.

- Reinforcing the knowledge that this is a temporary situation and normalcy will return.

Please click the link below to access this free content with your child. #ALLINMartinğŸ‘Š
